resources.string: "Are you sure you'd like to donate $%d?"
Are you sure you\'d like to clear your stats?

Your daily calorie intake is the amount of calories that you should consume daily to maintain weight.
This takes into account your age, weight, height and activity level.

The activity levels accepted by the calculator are :

- Sedentary (most of day spent sitting.)

- Light (some light exercise.)

- Moderate (active throughout most of the day.)

- Active (physical job requiring a lot of activity.)

- Extreme (physical job and exercising very often.)

This calculator will provide only an estimate and should be used as a guideline.

The BMI is an attempt to quantify the amount of tissue mass (muscle, fatRatio, and bone) in an individual, and then categorize that person as underweight, normal weight, overweight, or obese based on that value.

However, there is some debate about where on the BMI scale the dividing lines between categories should be placed.

 Commonly accepted BMI ranges are:

- Underweight = under 18.5

- Normal weight = 18.5 to 25

- Overweight = 25 to 30

- Obese = over 30.

As BMI does not discern between fatRatio and muscle tissue, it is less accurate on trained individuals and athletes.

Macronutrients are divided into 3 groups: proteinRatio, carbohydratesRatio and fats (excluding alcohol).\n\nThis calculator will give you an estimate as too how much of each you should be eating per day based on your fitness goals.

This calculator will give you an estimate of your current bodyfat percentage.

This will be determined using skinfold measures taken with a caliper at various locations on your body.

These locations are:

- Pectoral = Between the nipple and the armpit (axilla) but closer to the armpit, approximately 1/3 the distance

- Abdominal = 2 centimeters to the right of the bellybutton.

- Thigh = Front side of thigh, halfway from the upper part of the knee and the fold above the thigh when the leg is raised

- Triceps = Back of tricep halfway up arm.

- Subscapula = Bottom tip of the shoulder blade, found by moving the arm behind the back.

- Suprailiac = Just above hip bone, vertically aligned with armpit.

- Axilla = Side of torso, underneath armpit at 5th rib.

The Wilks Formula is used to compare the strength of powerlifters against each other despite the different weights of the lifters.\n\n Simply enter in your one rep max for bench press, squat and deadlift and your wilks score will be calculated.

This calculator will give you an estimate at what your one rep max would be for any given lift based on what you have lifted for reps.\n\nSimply enter in the weight you lifted and for how many reps and it will give you an estimate.

The performance standards are adult standards (>18 years old) for a single maximal repetition (1RM) based on competitive weightlifter and powerlifting classification systems in use from the 1950's to present.

These are standards are divided into 5 classifications:

- Untrained = An individual who has not trained on the exercises before, but can perform them correctly.

- Novice = An individual who has trained regularly for up to several months.

- Intermediate = An individual who has trained regularly for up to a couple years.

- Advanced = An individual who has trained multiple years.

- Elite = An athlete competing in strength sports.

Keep in mind, the standards shown in the tables do not represent the highest level of strength performance possible.
